title: Setup & Authentication
description: Install Firebase CLI and manage accounts

cards.description: Installs the Firebase command-line tools globally so you can use the 'firebase' command from any directory.
cards.whenToUse: First-time setup before using any Firebase CLI features.
scenarios: Initial setup: Installing Firebase tools on a new development machine
Version upgrade: Reinstalling to get the latest Firebase CLI version
CI/CD setup: Adding Firebase tools to your build environment

cards.task: Log in to Firebase from the command line
cards.description: Opens a browser window to authenticate with your Google account and authorize the Firebase CLI.
cards.whenToUse: When you need to connect the CLI to your Firebase account for the first time or after logging out.
scenarios: First-time authentication: Connecting CLI to your Google account
Account switch: Re-authenticating after logging out
New machine: Setting up Firebase CLI on a different computer

cards.description: Signs out of the Firebase CLI and removes cached credentials from your machine.
cards.whenToUse: When switching accounts or for security on shared machines.
scenarios: Account switching: Logging out before switching to a different Google account
Security: Removing credentials from a shared or public machine
Troubleshooting: Clearing credentials to fix authentication issues

cards.task: Add an additional Google account to Firebase CLI
cards.description: Authorizes another Google account for use with the CLI without logging out of the current one.
cards.whenToUse: When you work with Firebase projects across multiple Google accounts.
scenarios: Multi-account workflow: Adding work and personal accounts
Team access: Adding an account with access to different projects
Client work: Adding a client's account temporarily

cards.description: Shows all Google accounts currently authorized with the Firebase CLI.
cards.whenToUse: When you need to see which accounts are available for use.
scenarios: Account management: Checking which accounts are currently authorized
Troubleshooting: Verifying the correct account is logged in
Cleanup: Reviewing accounts before removing unused ones

cards.task: Log in without opening a browser (for remote/CI environments)
cards.description: Provides a URL to authenticate manually, useful for remote servers or CI environments without a browser.
cards.whenToUse: When working on a headless server or in a CI/CD pipeline.
scenarios: Remote server: Authenticating on a server via SSH
CI/CD pipeline: Setting up authentication in automated environments
Docker container: Logging in from a containerized environment
